member.name: T:Ensoftener.ComputeShaderBase
member.summary: A compute shader effect inherited from . You can modify its input count, constant buffer and its nodes.

remarks.b: Requires EnsoftenerCpp32.dll or EnsoftenerCpp64.dll in to be put in your program directory.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.ComputeShaderBase.#ctor(System.Guid)
member.summary: Initializes a new custom effect.
member.param: The GUID of the effect. Each GUID has one compute shader assigned to it.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.ComputeShaderBase.CalculateThreadgroups(SharpDX.Mathematics.Interop.RawRectangle)
member.summary: The amount of tiles of the image to render. The tile size is specified by the [numthreads] attribute in the compute shader, in pixels.
member.remarks: If your tiles don't cover the whole image, only a portion of the image will render.

member.name: T:Ensoftener.Global
member.summary: The class containing everything necessary, from Direct2D components to new and useful DeviceContext methods.

member.name: F:Ensoftener.Global.BitmapProperties
member.summary: The bitmap properties used for rendering. If you're creating a new bitmap, use these as a parameter.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.FinalDC
member.summary: The final device context that renders on screen, and the only one that uses byte color depth. Updates after is called.
member.remarks: If you want to take a screenshot of the screen and convert it into a GDI bitmap, use on this context for the fastest performance. If you were to convert any context from to GDI, it would take much longer, as the other contexts use . In that case, the library would cast every individual float from the screen to a byte, which takes about half a second. Since the final context's pixel format is , it's the easiest and fastest to copy.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.SwapChainDescription
member.summary: 's creation specs (in case you need them).

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.ShaderFile
member.summary: A .cso file that will be loaded by every pixel or compute shader created from now on. One shader class can have different pixel shaders for every instance.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.VertexShaderFile
member.summary: A .cso file that will be loaded by every vertex shader created from now on. One shader class can have different vertex shaders for every instance.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.D2DFactory

member.remarks: Based on D2DDevice.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.D2DDevice
member.remarks: Based on D3DDevice.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.D3DDevice

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.SwapChain
member.remarks: Based on D3DDevice and a DXGIFactory.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.DWriteFactory
member.summary: The class passed as a parameter when rendering text.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.WICFactory

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.ExistingEffects
member.summary: A list of all effects that were created.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.OutputSetup
member.summary: The setup that will serve as the output and present its contents to the screen.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.DrawingSetup.DC
member.summary: The DeviceContext used for rendering everything, probably the most used class of them all.
member.remarks: Based on D2DDevice.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.DrawingSetup.RenderTarget
member.summary: The render target of the DeviceContext. Any changes of the target will apply to the device context as well.
member.remarks: Based on DeviceContext.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.DrawingSetup.ResizeWithScreen
member.summary: Set this context to be resizable with the screen.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.DrawingSetup.UseOnlyOneTile
member.summary: The context's tile size will be equal to the context's size. The setting will take effect after the window is moved or resized.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.DrawingSetup.ApplySettings(System.Nullable{System.Boolean},System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Changes settings of the setup and applies them. Set values to null to leave them as they are.
member.param: The property.
The property.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.DrawingSetup.#ctor(System.Nullable{SharpDX.Size2},System.Nullable{SharpDX.Size2},System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a new rendering setup.
member.param: The size of the context's target
The property. By default it's 64Ã—64 or the window size if is set to true.
The property.
The property.

Create the context with 32-bit float color depth (128bpp) instead of 8-bit byte color depth (32bpp).
Graphics-wise, floats are more useful, as they allow for colors to be "whiter than white" (or more than 1) and "blacker than black" (negative), which is useful for pixel shaders.
Performance-wise, bytes are faster if you're converting to GDI bitmaps often, and require 4 times less memory.
You won't need to use bytes unless you need to solve one of these two issues.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Global.DrawingSetup.TileSize
member.summary: The maximum allowed size of tiles the shader will be split into. The tiles will not use this exact size, but they will never exceed this size.
member.remarks: Setting the tile size both to a small amount or a large amount has disadvantages. Since texture coordinates in shaders are determined by tiles, the position in both pixel and compute shaders starts at the top left corner of each tile. Setting to true solves this issue, but rendering shaders will be slower, as the GPU tries to render the whole image at once.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.DrawingSetup.RenderScreenShaders(System.Boolean,SharpDX.Direct2D1.Effect[])
member.summary: Batch renders an array of effects applied to the entire screen.
member.param: The array of effects to render.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.Initialize(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Nullable{SharpDX.Size2})
member.summary: Creates all the stuff needed for a basic SharpDX setup. The first device (0th) will be set as output.
member.param: The amount of parallel Direct2D setups to create (for multirendering). All components will be accessible from their lists. Cannot be less than 1.
Crashes if a shader takes more than 2 seconds to execute. Useful when testing out shaders with loops.
The default size of all device contexts, except for the outputting one. By default it's the window size.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.Run(System.Action,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts displaying the window and runs the rendering loop.
member.param: The method that will be called on each monitor refresh.
member.remarks: Do not use this for updating game logic! The is dependent on your monitor refresh rate (60x or 144x per second). Instead, create a second thread that's called every 1/60th of a second.
member.param: Updates mouse+keyboard input in this thread. This is very important to look after, as updating input while another thread is running can have consequences if the other thread relies on this input.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.RunSideThread(System.Action,System.Int64,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts another updating loop after the window shows up, independent from your monitor's refresh rate. The thread will be then attached to the main one and will accept inputs as well.
member.param: The method to call each update.
The amount of ticks to wait until next call. A tick is 100 nanoseconds long, so 166666 ticks is about 1/60th of a second.
Updates mouse+keyboard input in this thread. This is very important to look after, as updating input while another thread is running can have consequences if the other thread relies on this input.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.Quit
member.summary: Schedules a shutdown of the window. After the current rendering method ends, all sounds are stopped and components deleted.
member.remarks: Windows doesn't allow for different threads to close a single window, which means the closure needs to be scheduled for later and then executed by the window thread.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.EndRender
member.summary: Presents the final output on screen. Put this at the end of your render method.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.RemoveSetup(System.Int32)
member.summary: Disposes of a setup and removes it from the lists.

member.summary: Creates a SharpDX Bitmap off of a GDI+ bitmap.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Global.ToGDIBitmap(SharpDX.Direct2D1.Bitmap1)
member.summary: Creates a GDI+ bitmap off of a SharpDX Bitmap. Very slow if using float colors.
member.remarks: If you're taking a screenshot, use to get the final rendering result. always uses byte colors, which means the screenshot process is fairly quick.

member.returns: The render target's bitmap. Requires a newer version of DirectX and cannot be read by the GPU.

member.summary: Copies the device context's render target for further GPU processing (such as shaders).
member.returns: The render target's bitmap. The bitmap cannot be read by the CPU.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.Input.XboxInput.XboxController.Vibrate(System.UInt16,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Vibrates the controller infinitely (until set to 0).
member.param: The strength of the motor on the left side, from 0 to 65535.
The strength of the motor on the right side, from 0 to 65535. The right motor vibrates more "smoothly" than the left motor.
member.remarks: Not all values actually influence the strength, the motors have only several steps of vibration intensity.

member.name: T:Ensoftener.PVShaderBase
member.summary: A more or less functional shader effect inherited from . You can modify its input count, constant buffer, its nodes, splittable data stream designed for passing vertices and the shader's semantics.
member.remarks:
The effect consists of a vertex shader and a pixel shader. The vertex shader stage deforms the bitmap via a triangular mesh and the pixel shader stage can create additional color filters on top of the deformed triangles. Either can be turned off in the constructor, but disabling both may result in errors.
The vertex shader is still WIP - 100% functionality isn't guaranteed.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.PVShaderBase.#ctor(System.Nullable{System.Guid},System.Nullable{System.Guid},System.Nullable{System.Guid},System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new custom effect.
member.param: The GUID of the effect. Each GUID has one pixel shader assigned to it, hence the 's ability to have different pixel shaders.
The GUID of the vertex shader.
The GUID of the vertex buffer. The vertex buffer contains values that will be passed to the shader, not the shader itself.
Enable the pixel shader stage in this effect.
Enable the vertex shader stage in this effect.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.PVShaderBase.VertexCount
member.summary: The amount of vertices processed by the vertex shader. The amount must be a multiple of 3, as every 3 vertices form a single face.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.PVShaderBase.VsInBuffer
member.summary: A stream of structs assigned to semantics in vertex shaders. Streams can be created off of arrays via (set canRead and canWrite to true!). The extra int indicates the size of each struct.
member.remarks:
A vertex buffer in vertex shaders works differently than a constant buffer in pixel shaders (if you're looking for an eqiuvalent, that's b1). Here, each vertex will get one struct in the array and recieve it via semantics in its main method. decides what parts of the struct will be assigned to each semantic.
While the struct can be literally anything, certain restrictions apply:
The struct must contain only value types (such as ).
All structs must be the same size, because the stream progresses by a fixed integer (second output) and would become offset.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.PVShaderBase.InputElements
member.summary: Returns an array of semantics that will be assigned to a part of each struct from . The offset of an element specifies the offset of a struct's s region that's assigned, in bytes. The format specifies what type will be assigned to the semantic.
member.remarks: For example, if contains structs with 8 floats each and there's an named "ABC" with an offset of 16 and format of , the vertex shader will recieve the struct's 5th, 6th and 7th float as a float3 under the ABC semantic.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.PVShaderBase.ReloadVertexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Updates the vertex buffer according to .
member.param: Reloads the same .cso file as before (otherwise uses .

member.name: T:Ensoftener.CloneablePixelShader
member.summary: A shader with no constant buffer, no inside effects and 1 texture input. Its GUID is different for every instance, which means it can load a different shader every time.

member.summary: Volume of the sound between 0 and 1.

member.summary: Speed of the sound, without changed pitch. 1 is normal.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Sound.ISoundGeneric.Length

member.name: T:Ensoftener.Sound.WMPSound
member.summary: A simplified version of that's easier to understand. You also don't need to include the WMPLib namespace which would normally require specifying <UseWindowsForms>true</UseWindowsForms> in your .csproj file.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Sound.WMPSound.FilePath
member.summary: The location of the sound. It can be a local file or a website URL.
member.remarks: On Chrome, website sound file will appear as a black page with a small player in the middle. If that's the case, then you've got the sound's URL.

remarks.b: This value does not work in this class.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Sound.WMPSound.Metadata
member.summary: Gets the song's metadata. This method requests all possible keys, so at the end you might get a dictionary of 100 empty keyvalues.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Sound.WMPSound.Length
member.summary: Length of the sound, in seconds.
member.remarks: This value only works when the sound is playing.

member.name: T:Ensoftener.Sound.WPFSound
member.summary: A variant of that's ported from WPF to Windows Forms. You also don't need to specify <UseWPF>true</UseWPF> in your .csproj file.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Sound.WPFSound.FilePath
member.summary: The location of the sound. It can be a local file or a website URL.
member.remarks: On Chrome, website sound file will appear as a black page with a small player in the middle. If that's the case, then you've got the sound's URL.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Sound.CSWSound.Speed
member.summary: Speed of the sound, with changed pitch. 1 is normal. Changing speed reloads all components (including the source file) and should be used sparingly

member.name: T:Ensoftener.Sound.CSWSound.CSWSoundModifier.CSWSoundSampleData
member.summary: Contains information about the audio stream.

member.name: F:Ensoftener.Sound.CSWSound.CSWSoundModifier.CSWSoundSampleData.Buffer
member.summary: The array of samples to be modified for this frame. Because the modifier is called every latency interval, the array's length is usually the sample rate multiplied by latency (44100 * 0.1s = 4410).

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Sound.CSWSound.CSWSoundModifier.Modifier
member.summary: Modifies every sound wave that's being played.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.Sound.CSWSound.CSWSoundModifier.ModifierAdvanced
member.summary: Like , modifies sound waves that are being played, except that this also recieves all of the streaming data, including the direct access to the array of samples.
member.remarks: To implement a working modifier, create a for loop that starts at the offset and ends at offset + count. That way, you modify every relevant sample that actually plays in the speaker.

member.name: T:Ensoftener.SvgImage
member.summary: A SVG image that can be modified at runtime.
member.remarks: If you're planning to apply position, rotation and scale to your SVG, make sure that all shapes in the SVG are grouped by <g> elements. Some editors don't group them by default, in which case you have to group them. On the other hand, make sure the editor didn't already apply a transform to the groups, because that's going to be overriden.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.UpdateIfOutdated
member.summary: Rebuilds the SVG everytime the Outdated is set to true.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.Outdated
member.summary: Direct2D-controlled SVG elements are less accessible than in a normal XML parser, and therefore can go out of sync. This flag indicates that the SVG needs to be recreated.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.X
member.summary: X position of the SVG.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.Y
member.summary: Y position of the SVG.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.Rotation
member.summary: Rotation of the SVG, clockwise, in degrees.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.Width
member.summary: Width multiplier of the SVG.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.Height
member.summary: Height multiplier of the SVG.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.Matrix
member.summary: Transform matrix of the SVG. This applies on top of the other translations.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.SvgImage.#ctor(SharpDX.Direct2D1.DeviceContext,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates an SVG image from a file or an XML string.
member.param: The file path or XML string.
Determines whether to read from a file or from the string itself.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.SvgImage.Rebuild
member.summary:
Recreates the SVG image. See the description of the property for why this needs to be done.
This method is automatically called when is set to true.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.SvgElement1.Attributes
member.summary: Gets all attribute names that exist in this element.

member.name: M:Ensoftener.SvgImage.SvgElement1.DissectAttribute(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Some elements may contain an attribute (such as "style") that packs multiple attributes into one. This method dissects it back.
member.param: The attribute to be dissected.
Override existing attributes by the new and dissected ones.
member.remarks: This method outdates the image.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.SvgElement1.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Gets or sets an attribute by its name.
member.remarks: This method outdates the image.

member.name: P:Ensoftener.SvgImage.SvgElement1.Item(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Gets an attribute by its name and returns if nothing is found.
member.remarks: If you're trying to get a shape's coordinates, you might want to use this with set to 0. Some SVG editors like Boxy leave out this attribute if the shape is located at (0, 0) and same thing could happen in other cases as well.
